<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_ExecTput:
```c
static void OS_BSP_ExecTput(const char *cap, const char *param)
{
    pid_t cpid;
    int   status;

    cpid = fork();
    if (cpid < 0)
    {
        return;
    }
    if (cpid == 0)
    {
        execlp("tput", "tput", cap, param, NULL);
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }
    waitpid(cpid, &status, 0);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions are used in the provided code. The fragment uses standard C features (static function, return, if, comparisons, calls) and POSIX library/system calls (fork, execlp, waitpid, pid_t, exit, EXIT_FAILURE). POSIX APIs are platform/system interfaces, not compiler language extensions. There are no GCC/Clang-specific constructs such as __attribute__, __asm__, asm(...), typeof, statement expressions ({: ... :}), nested functions, __builtin_* identifiers, or pragma/extension directives that compilers document as language extensions. Therefore no code fragments require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (use of language extensions).
